div.head: To the very vertuous and my singular good Lady, the Lady Leighton, one of the Ladies of the Queenes Maiesties most honorable priuie Chamber: the Pilgrime wisheth a long and happie life, with such increase of honour, as her Ladiships godly indeuours doe deserue.
div.p:
HOw farre little Englande (my verie good Ladie) doeth in perfecte felicitie surpasse all the large kingdomes of the worlde, that trauell and small experience which I haue had, hath sufficiently taught mee: and in truth (were it not that the generall plentie of passing much happinesse, doth make a great multitude of people to forget in many respectes their dueties,) I would without doubting stedfastly beleeue that the Sunne it selfe neither doth, nor euer hath shined vppon any place, whose prosperitie might compare with this Ilandes: brought in deede to that worthie passe by the great good gouernmēt & singuler industry of the Queenes Maiesties most excellent wisdome. The due consideration wherof, did moue mee continually to force my selfe in the praise of so great a personage, and finding my weakenesse equall with mine vnworthines, I was still restrained from that attēpt, and had indeede neuer attempted but that necessitie
constraineth the ignoraunt to speake when the learned be silent, & the truth may with great commendation be vttered out of the mouth of a childe. At my last return out of the maine Ocean, being entred into that brod & boystrous bay of Portingale, there (I may truely say) amongest the moste mightie and greatest ouergrowne Seas in the worlde, the strength of my desire so preuailed, as it forced me (euen there) solemnely to vow, presently after mine arriuall I woulde indeuour to straine my breath to the vttermost, so to sounde foorth her excellent praise, who of a barbarous Ile hath made a most florishing common wealth. And beeing arriued in that pleasant Tempe, immediatly solitarie contemplation so acquainted mee with the heauenly diuine powers, that not by imagination, but with present familiare conference, I was continually conuersaunt with the Muses, with all learnings Ladies, euen with the ansient Gods and Goddesses themselues, who haue repaide my diligent seruice with a small habilitie to vse my penne as a proper instrumente against yrkesome idlenes, and a sharpe swoorde to vanquishe her brutish daughter blinde ignorance mother to error, the dreadfull vndoer of mankinde. By this meanes I filled of late fiue queeres of paper with mine owne deuises, if a mā may esteeme that his which the great worldemaker, I knowe not by what secrete diuine infusion conuaieth into him, which booke for that it is in deed but a brief repetitiō of the Queenes maiesties due deserued praises, therfore I did intitle it
A Reuelation of the true Minerua: in whithe discourse for that it pleaseth many of the worthiest that euer liued to vtter some speeches in the praise of her most excellent Maiestie, and to surrender and resigne ouer their titles, beeing as it woulde seemee, prouoked thereto by her maiesties due desarts, I not able to cōceale that part, haue abruptly rent it from the reste which made it once more beautifull. And because your Ladiships exceeding great wisdom hath made you a very worthy mēber of her maiesties most roiall Courte, and hath inriched you with such credite as you may mightily defende all godly and good indeuours, hauing your place continually very neere vnto her maiesties elbow, therfore I haue set foorth this first part vnder your tuition, hoping that the matter therein contained shall please euen as many as shall reade it, and thus your Ladiships most humble seruant doth end, wishing vnto you in euery respect your heartes desires.
